caseStudies.title: Reducing workflow friction in a high-volume internal system

images.alt: ICP workflow diagram showing progressive disclosure and step-by-step process
images.caption: Redesigned workflow breaking complex tasks into clear, predictable steps

images.alt: ICP interface showing document preview and validation
images.caption: Preview and validation interface reducing errors before document generation

sections.heading: Context & Stakes
content: SSA staff use internal systems to generate official communications that directly affect the public. When those systems are difficult to use or error-prone, the consequences are real — delays, rework, and loss of confidence.

I was brought in to design a clearer, more reliable document-creation experience that supported staff under real operational constraints while meeting strict accessibility and compliance requirements.

sections.heading: Key Design Decisions
bullets: Broke a complex workflow into clear, predictable steps
Used progressive disclosure to manage cognitive load
Prioritized preview and validation before document generation
Aligned UI patterns with SSA standards and accessibility requirements

sections.heading: Research & Insight
content: Usability research revealed where the system was asking users to compensate for poor structure — particularly during template selection, data entry, and final review. These breakdowns directly informed design decisions.

sections.heading: Accessibility
content: Accessibility was treated as a baseline design constraint, informing layout, interaction patterns, focus order, and content structure from the start.

sections.heading: Outcome
content: The redesigned workflow improved task confidence, reduced perceived complexity, and supported more reliable document creation during usability testing.

sections.heading: Reflection
content: Clarity isn't about simplifying reality — it's about supporting people within it.

caseStudies.title: Creating consistency and accessibility at enterprise scale
caseStudies.client: Social Security Administration · Enterprise UX Design System

images.alt: SSA design system component library showing buttons, forms, and navigation patterns
images.caption: Reusable component library ensuring consistency across applications

images.alt: Design system documentation showing accessibility guidelines and usage patterns
images.caption: Comprehensive documentation supporting cross-team adoption

sections.heading: Context
content: The Social Security Administration needed a unified design system to ensure consistency and accessibility across dozens of internal and public-facing applications. Without shared standards, teams were duplicating effort and creating inconsistent experiences.
I contributed to building and documenting a scalable design system that could serve diverse teams while maintaining strict accessibility and compliance standards.

sections.heading: Outcome
content: The design system provided teams with reusable, accessible components and clear guidance, reducing design and development time while improving consistency across SSA's digital ecosystem.

sections.heading: Reflection
content: Good systems work quietly in the background, enabling teams to focus on solving problems rather than reinventing solutions.

caseStudies.title: Modernizing a public platform without breaking trust
caseStudies.client: U.S. Department of Labor · Women's Bureau

images.alt: Information architecture diagram showing restructured content hierarchy
images.caption: Restructured information architecture providing clearer paths to content

images.alt: Accessible page templates for the Women's Bureau website
images.caption: Consistent, accessible templates improving editorial workflows

sections.heading: Context
content: The Women's Bureau website serves a broad public audience seeking research, programs, and resources related to women in the workforce. The legacy site was difficult to navigate, content-heavy, and challenging to maintain.
I supported the Drupal 8 modernization by focusing on content structure, accessibility, and long-term sustainability — balancing public needs with internal editorial workflows.

sections.heading: Outcome
content: The modernized site gave users clearer paths to information while giving internal teams a more stable, maintainable content foundation.

sections.heading: Reflection
content: Public-facing systems earn trust through clarity, consistency, and care.
